item.title: Architecture and Electricity
item.description:
Filip Burno’s book Architektura i elektryczność. 1880–1940. Konstruowanie, doświadczanie, reprezentacja [Architecture and Electricity: 1880–1940: Constructing, Experiencing, Representation] was published by the Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw in 2025. It is a richly illustrated study of the use of electrical energy and artificial lighting in construction.

My goal was to create a graphic design for the publication that would harmonise with the presented iconography. Monochromatic archival visuals determined the black-and-white, minimalist character of the book. Yellow appears only on the cover, referencing the glow of the illuminated glass façades and building interiors. The publication contains meticulously selected photographs, architectural drawings, diagrams, and propaganda materials.

item.title: This Road Was Endless
item.description: The exhibition This Road Was Endless: On Stanisław Staszewski, dedicated to the architect, singer and artist known primarily as Tata Kazika [Kazik’s Father], was opened at the end of 2025 at the Adam Mickiewicz Museum of Literature in Warsaw. It was curated by three researchers of Staszewski’s life and work: Krzysztof Gajda, Maciej Kubiak, and Przemysław Lembicz. I supported them by developing the exhibition design, typography and two neon signs.

item.title: Hidden Remains
item.description:
Hidden Remains. Centrally Planned Housing of the Polish Countryside was an exhibition held at the Museum of Architecture in Wrocław from 4 December 2025 to 5 April 2026. Curated by the PROLOG studio in collaboration with the museum team, the exhibition explored the architecture of centrally planned farms in the Polish People’s Republic.

Photos by Jerzy Wypych

I was responsible for the exhibition’s visual identity, including posters, typographic elements, and infographics. The poster design featured photographs by Jędrzej Sokołowski and used: the RL Limo headline typeface by Radek Łukasiewicz and the Tekio Grotesk Medium by Jan Estrada-Osmycki.

item.title: No Ghosts on Good Street
item.description: Based on a 3D model created by the Fireplace post-production studio, I designed a poster for Emi Buchwald’s award-wining debut. I also prepared the typographic layer for the film.

item.title: Clay, Sinter, Form
item.description:
The exhibition of ceramics from the collections of the State Ethnographic Museum in Warsaw emphasizes the physicality of the process of creating clay vessels. The objects presented at the exhibition play a key role in a series of posters advertising the event. Using basic visual tools—framing, multiplication, and rythym—I composed micro-scenes and interpreted the stories contained within the objects.

I based the visual identity on a color palette that includes several earthy, clay shades and a complementary purple. Thanks to this, the colors of objects do not clash with the background and you can always choose the right background contrast.

item.title: Bleaching
item.description:
The exhibition “Bleaching” concerns the colonial origins of part of the Etnographic Museum’s collection. The visual communication concept is based on two elements: a graphic, symbolic title and a minimalistic typographic frame containing additional information. I created the poster and a graphic design for the exhibition.

The promotional campaign took place on the streets of Warsaw and online. The typography in the exhibition was printed directly onto the walls using a mobile printer.

item.title: The Phenomenal
item.description:
The exhibition The Phenomenal: Zdzisław Beksiński took place from April 13 to August 24, 2025, at the National Museum in Wrocław. I developed the visual identity and display design, as well as the design of the catalog accompanying the exhibition.

Zdzisław Beksiński is currently known mainly as a painter, but in the 1950s and 1960s he was involved in photography. Aleksandra Szwedo, the exhibition curator, selected over 150 of his black-and-white photographs, which are characterized by exceptionally precise compositions.

item.title: Don’t hate the player, hate the game
item.description:
“Bielska jesień” [Bielsko Autumn] is the most important painting competition in Poland, held every two years. In the years between editions, a curated exhibition is organised.

In 2024, the exhibition was titled Don’t hate the player, hate the game, curated by Janek Owczarek and Piotr Policht. The curators explored the relationship between painting and the art market, presenting examples of how artists navigate galleries, collectors, and their own creative needs. item.title: A Slice of the World
item.description:
The book, written by historian Błażej Brzostek and published by the Museum of Warsaw, serves as a guidebook that presents a concise history of Poland’s capital through selected objects from the Museum’s collection.

The graphic design of the book received the Must Have quality mark during the Łódź Design Festival.
